definition.en: Dark spots (hyperpigmentation) are areas of skin that appear darker than the surrounding skin due to excess melanin production. Common types include age spots, sun spots, melasma, and post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation.

causes: Sun exposure and UV radiation (primary cause)
prevention: Wear SPF 50+ sunscreen daily (even indoors, cloudy days)
Wear wide-brimmed hats and protective clothing
Seek shade during peak sun hours (10 AM - 4 PM)
Use physical sunscreen (zinc oxide, titanium dioxide)
Treat acne promptly to prevent PIH
Don't pick at skin or acne

mild.description: Light brown spots, few in number, not very visible

moderate.description: Multiple spots, darker coloration, more noticeable

severe.description: Dark, stubborn spots, widespread, melasma, resistant to treatment

whenToSeeDermatologist: Dark spots don't fade after 3 months of treatment
Spots are growing or changing in appearance
Spots are black or have irregular borders (rule out skin cancer)

statistics.prevalence: 90% of people over 60 have age spots
statistics.melasma: Affects 5-6 million people in US, 90% are women
statistics.treatmentTime: Typically takes 3-6 months to see significant fading

types.sunspots: Brown spots from UV damage, common after 40
types.ageSpots: Also called liver spots or solar lentigines
types.melasma: Brown or gray-brown patches, often on face, hormonal
types.pih: Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation from acne or injury
types.freckles: Small brown spots, genetic, darkened by sun

myths.fact: Most dark spots can fade with consistent treatment and sun protection, though some stubborn spots may require professional procedures.
While darker skin has more natural protection, it's still susceptible to UV damage and hyperpigmentation. SPF is essential for all skin tones.

myths.myth: Lemon juice can fade dark spots
myths.fact: Lemon juice can irritate skin and make pigmentation worse. It's phototoxic and can cause burns when exposed to sun.

myths.myth: You only need SPF in summer
myths.fact: UV rays penetrate year-round, even on cloudy days. Daily SPF is essential for preventing and treating dark spots.

morning: Reapply SPF every 2 hours if outdoors
evening: Alpha arbutin or kojic acid serum

tips: Choose physical/mineral sunscreen (zinc oxide, titanium dioxide)
Apply 1/4 teaspoon for face, reapply every 2 hours
Apply SPF 20 minutes before sun exposure
